awd_titl_txt: A Bio-Cultural Study of Preferences, Behaviors, and Outcomes in Family Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-marital births are an increasingly common occurrence around the world. In 2013, they accounted for two-fifths of births in the United States and an even higher proportion in much of the rest of the world. Marital dissolution also occurs at high rates and across cultures, infidelity is one of the most commonly cited reasons for divorce. Traditionally, marital dissolution has been associated with negative consequences for both mothers and children, including poorer health, lower socio-economic status, and lower educational attainment. This raises the question about why women choose to switch or maintain partners and whether there are circumstances under which doing one or the other might be beneficial. University of California-Los Angeles anthropologist, Dr. Brooke Scelza, will lead a team to conduct a bio-cultural investigation of the causes and consequences of female partnership selectivity to understand the significance of these worldwide shifts in 21st century family dynamics.

A scientific study requires that the factors behind these behaviors be disaggregated from potentially confounding variables. This requires that the research be conducted in a smaller-scale and more isolated group than can be found in the United States. Therefore, the researchers will travel to northwest Namibia where they can study the Himba, a semi-nomadic pastoralist group. The Himba provide an appropriate research site because they have high rates of divorce, self-reported infidelity, and non-marital births. If these behaviors benefit women over their lifespans, these benefits should show up in Himba data. The research team will first document Himba cultural models of family and relationship dynamics. They will then compare these models to actual behaviors, using data from marital and reproductive histories. This will allow them to assess how often women's behaviors match preferences, which women are most likely to have partners that meet their ideals, and when alternative strategies of non-marital reproduction are most likely to occur. Finally, the consequences of having multiple partners will be assessed by tracking resource transfers and health outcomes. Findings from this research will help social scientists understand the significance of changing marital patterns and alternative reproductive strategies wherever they occur. The research will also provide insight into why women seek non-traditional partnerships, which is essential for developing practical and effective outreach and social services.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this NSF project was to challenge our current understanding of marriage and family, by investigating the role of concurrent and sequential partnerships in a society where such relationship practices are common and largely destigmatized, the Himba of northwest Namibia. Through the construction of a multifaceted demographic and ethnographic database we were able to explore the dynamics of Himba romantic partnerships, identify differences in the form and function of formal (marital) versus informal (nonmarital) relationships, and understand the costs and benefits of having multiple partners in this particular socioecological context. Along the way we explored how and why women might be more open to having multiple partners at different points in their lifespan, and in response to particular conditions like resource stress and food insecurity, as well as how men invest in children based on their beliefs about paternity. Through the design and construction of a novel, tablet-based method for collecting data on people's opinions of others in their community we were able to study this "local mating market" in detail--combining demographic and ethnographic data with peer ratings on various  traits (e.g. generosity, attractiveness) and partner preferences. This is the most extensive such study done outside of a western, industrialized nation to date. In addition, we collected hundreds of DNA samples and were able to ascertain the rate of nonpaternity (children fathered by someone other than the husband) and recorded the highest known rate at 48%. Combined with data showing a high rate of accuracy by Himba men and women, we were able to explore the dual roles of social and biological fatherhood in this society, showing that Himba believe strongly in treating children equally, regardless of paternity, and showing that this largely holds true across various measures of paternal care.

The multimodal research design for this project generated a number of novel methodologies and tools that should be useful to social scientists at large. First, a longitudinal, relational database was created that could easily combine various types of data: interviews, relationship histories, anthropometrics, wealth counts, social network data, etc. Several researchers on other projects have already requested (and have received) a template of our database for use in their own work. In addition, we generated several novel behavioral experiments including a "Giving Game" that looked at allocations of resources across different types of romantic partners, counterfactual vignettes that measure norm change, and several picture-based question sets that use images to assess people's preferences. Finally, the trait and partner preference tool that we created for the ipad was able to generate tens of thousands of ratings over a relatively short period--a method which we are just beginning to publish on, but which we anticipate will be broadly useful to psychologists, anthropologists and sociologists studying partnership dynamics.

This project contributed to the training of emerging scholars at various levels. One postdoctoral scholar was trained over a three year period, and has now transitioned into a tenure-track job. Another three PhD students are using data from the project in their MA and dissertation research. Two other postdoctoral scholars were able to come to the field, and were co-authors on resulting publications. And numerous undergraduates have worked on the project, entering data and learning laboratory techniques. During the course of this grant we were also able to establish partnerships with scientists at the University of Namibia, with whom we will continue to work in the future.

Finally, this project has contribted to the small but important set of longitudinal fieldsites around the world studying human behavior at both the individual and community levels. We have strived to foreground community involvement in the development of our methods and in the dissemination of our results. As cross-cultural social science research gains in popularity, we have aimed to set an example for how such work can be done ethically and responsibly. Therefore, in addition to publishing on the results of our work, we have also contributed to several methods and opinion pieces about the role of cross-cultural work in the social sciences.
